definitions.definition: unpleasant; real, and impossible to avoid

examples.text: The author paints a stark picture of life in a prison camp.
The government faced a stark choice between civil war and martial law.
The remains of the building stand as a stark reminder of the fire.
He now faces the **stark reality** of life in prison.
The stark truth is that there is not enough money left.
The stark fact is that even with more time, we still couldn’t raise enough money.

definitions.definition: very different from something in a way that is easy to see

examples.text: Social divisions in the city are stark.
The good weather was **in stark contrast to** the storms of previous weeks.

definitions.definition: looking severe and without any colour or decoration

examples.text: I think white would be too stark for the bedroom.
The hills stood stark against the winter sky.
The corridors were stark and uncarpeted.
The décor was rather stark for my taste.
The children watched in stark terror.

wordOrigin: Old English stearc ‘unyielding, severe’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch sterk and German stark ‘strong’.
